messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> This form of debugging requires visual inspection of the debug
> statements.

Debuggers, output/log statements, all these are tools that the
developer has at his disposal to perform his job (as another poster
suggests). Which one you chose will probably depend on which one you
feel most comfortable with.

I find that I understand the code much better using System.out
statements rather than trying to find my way round existing Java
debuggers, which IME have found lacking. (Maybe the suggestions in
this thread will help me change that.)

> Moreover, logging debug messages at this granularity tends to
> reduce the
> readability of the code, in my experience.

I agree. If you use debug output/log statements, they are there to
perform a specific task: find a bug. Once located and exterminated,
their function is over, take them out.

If you would like to document an aspect of the bug, try with an
assertion, where appropriate. Otherwise, document it with a test case
which exercises the bug. Thus, if modifying the code at a later date
you reinsert the bug, the test will catch this case and alert you.

>
> If I'm the poor sod who changes the code later, I'd rather have a
> set of tests
> that automatically check the results. That's not to say logging
> warning and error
> messages aren't valuable, just that analyzing debug statements
> requires more
> effort in the long run than writing tests.

As for logging statements, these are different from debug statements.
A debug statement will probably tell you whether you reached a
certain point in the code, the values of certain variables at that
point, in effect, for me, they take the place of the debugger. These
don't usually add any value later on.

Logging statements are different. They are there to add information.
You can still have logging statements at the debug level, but they
should be informative, rather than just: "The JVM woz 'ere!"
